overview: The measure has been amended to change the definition of "debilitating medical condition" to any condition determined by the certifying physician or advanced practice registered nurse to be appropriate for the medical use of cannabis. [12] The bill also amends the definition of "waiting room" to include an area where hemp and accessories to the use of medical cannabis can be sold. [12] Additionally, a new part has been added which prohibits operating a medical cannabis dispensary or cultivating cannabis without a license, establishes criminal penalties, and creates a new cannabis cultivator license. [12]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund the sum of $ or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [11] The funds are for the department of the attorney general to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, chapter 329D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [11] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the director of health for the purposes of this part. [11]
agency_impact: The measure now requires the Department of Health to issue a cease and desist notice to violators before initiating criminal proceedings for unlicensed cannabis operations. [12] It also establishes a cannabis cultivator license, requiring the Department of Health to issue and regulate this new license type. [12] The bill appropriates funds for the Department of Attorney General to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, chapter 329D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [12]
economic_impact: The bill amends the definition of "waiting room" to include an area where hemp can be sold, including but not limited to hemp products and accessories to the use of medical cannabis, such as rolling papers, rolling trays, grinders, and vaporizers. [11] This could create a new revenue stream for licensed dispensaries. [12] The establishment of a new cannabis cultivator license may also impact the market by creating a new class of business. [12]
policy_impact: The measure now amends the definition of "debilitating medical condition" to any condition determined by the certifying physician or advanced practice registered nurse to be appropriate for the medical use of cannabis. [11] A new cannabis cultivator license is established to authorize the cultivation and distribution of cannabis plants. [12] The bill also prohibits persons from operating a medical cannabis dispensary or cultivating cannabis without a license from the Department of Health and establishes criminal penalties for violations. [12]
revenue_sources: The measure appropriates funds out of the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund for the Department of Attorney General to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, chapter 329D, HRS. [11] The bill also authorizes expenditures from the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund to fund programs for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances relating to chapter 329D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [12]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates an unspecified sum from the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [11] This appropriation is for the department of the attorney general for enforcement and nuisance mitigation. [11] A new cannabis cultivator license is established, which will require ongoing resources from the Department of Health for issuance and oversight. [12] The department shall issue not more than one cannabis cultivator license for each person. [11] The maximum number of cannabis cultivator licenses that may be issued by the department to the public shall not exceed licenses. [11] The maximum size of plant canopy the department may authorize for each cannabis cultivator license shall be square feet for indoor cultivations and square feet for outdoor cultivations. [11] The Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund is now authorized to fund programs for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances, creating a new potential ongoing expenditure. [11]
operating_revenue_impact: The amendment to the definition of "waiting room" allows for an area where hemp can be sold, including but not limited to hemp products and accessories to the use of medical cannabis. [11] This change could generate additional operating revenue for licensed dispensaries. [12] The creation of a new cannabis cultivator license will also generate new license fee revenue for the state. [12]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The establishment of a cannabis cultivator license will create ongoing regulatory and oversight responsibilities for the Department of Health beyond the initial six-year period. [12] Enforcement activities by the Department of the Attorney General, funded by an initial two-year appropriation, will likely require sustained funding. [12] The authorization for the special fund to be used for nuisance abatement programs creates a potential for continued expenditures in the long term. [12]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure has been significantly amended by inserting the contents of S.B. No. 1064, S.D. 2. [12] A major policy change amends the definition of "debilitating medical condition" to any condition a certifying physician or advanced practice registered nurse determines to be appropriate for the medical use of cannabis. [12] The definition of "waiting room" is also amended to allow the sale of hemp products and accessories. [12] The bill now establishes a new cannabis cultivator license, prohibits unlicensed cannabis operations with criminal penalties, and requires the Department of Health to issue cease and desist notices before initiating criminal proceedings. [12] An appropriation from the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund has been added for the Department of Attorney General for enforcement and nuisance mitigation for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [12] The authorized uses of the special fund have been expanded to include funding for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances. [12]
